issue.title: JpaRepositroy unable to be proxied

labels.name: for: stackoverflow
labels.description: A question that's better suited to stackoverflow.com

issue.body:
When I defined an inner interface and extends JpaRepositroy ,there is no proxy object in spring.

So I got an error that:
 Parameter 0 of constructor in com.security.infra.repository.DefaultOauth2ClientRepository required a bean of type 'com.security.infra.repository.DefaultOauth2ClientRepository$Oauth2ClientJpaRepository' that could not be found.

here is the source code:
![image](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-data-jpa/assets/135929345/bb4694ce-7a2a-4a77-aaaf-3667817a819e)

issue.title: Provide an option to disable `JSqlParserQueryEnhancer`

labels.name: in: repository
labels.description: Repositories abstraction

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: A general enhancement

labels.name: status: feedback-provided
labels.description: Feedback has been provided

issue.body:
When JSqlParser is in classpath, the `org.springframework.data.jpa.repository.query.QueryEnhancerFactory` enables `org.springframework.data.jpa.repository.query.JSqlParserQueryEnhancer`.

However JSqlParser is quite CPU and memory allocation expensive, and it creates a new thread every time a query gets parsed.
Also, while the `JSqlParser` is very useful for various use cases, it is not perfect, and can not parse all the queries. We have encountered even bugs, when parsing a more complex SQL, goes to endless loop.

One of our services reported 15% more CPU total, just from this component.

Essentially, we have JSqlParser in classpath for other reasons, but don't want all the negative effects from `JSqlParserQueryEnhancer`.

Currently we disable it via byte-code manipulation:
```java
new ByteBuddy()
          .redefine(clazz)
          .method(named("isJSqlParserInClassPath"))
          .intercept(FixedValue.value(false))
          .make()
          .load(clazz.getClassLoader(), ClassReloadingStrategy.fromInstalledAgent());
```

However, it is not maintainable solution as we would most likely need to revisit this every time `spring-data-jpa` gets upgraded.

Please provide another mechanism, preferably a Spring Boot property, to disable this mechanism.

comment.body:
Any update for this issue and why is #3148 closed? 

We are facing the same problem. Due to the functionalities of our app, we have plenty of native queries in repositories, and the temporary threads created by JsqlParser bothers.

comment.body: Thanks for the detail. By default, nested repository definitions are ignored. Please add `@EnableJpaRepositories(considerNestedRepositories = true)` to your configuration to enable scanning for nested repository interfaces.

issue.title: Add the ability to set parameter values for Specifications ran via JpaSpecificationExecutor

labels.name: status: pending-design-work
labels.description: Needs design work before any code can be developed

labels.name: for: team-attention
labels.description: An issue we need to discuss as a team to make progress

issue.body:
It is possible via the CriteriaBuilder to set up parameters, but parameter values can't be set up if a Specification is ran via a spring repository (via JPASpecificationExecutor)

While it is certainly possible to create custom criterias/queries manually using the EntityManager, it is preferable to be able to set parameter values via Specification/Repository since it's a higher level API.

Using parameters instead of values/literals has multiple advantages:

- Better code design: separating the creation of a specification from the filter values that are applied during execution, especially when having dynamic Specifications with many user defined filter values.
- Shorter queries that don't necessarily leak certain information in the query: While Hibernate might automatically create parameters  and their values for certain Specifications (Notably cb.equal(Expression, Object)  if so configured, it can't do it for all cases, notably for cb.function where the arguments are Expression and you are forced to pass literals


This Pull Request adds a new record class ParametersValues in the same package as the Specification, that servers as a way to hold parameter name -> parameter values.

All methods in JPASpecificationExecutor that took Specifications as an argument now have variants that take ParametersValues as an argument as well

In the implementation in SimpleJpaRepository the methods without a ParamatersValues simply delegate their call to the counterparts with such an argument.

And the code that sets up the parameter values is mostly contained in the query creation code.

Test methods have been extended based on existing tests, but instead of using values, Specification using parameters were used instead.

The only test method that hasn't duplicated all tests is the findBy variant using a specification and a queryFunction
This is because the other tests verify mostly behaviour related to the queryFunction, and since the code is shared, only a single test was created to test that paramterValues are actually set

Thank you.

- [x ] You have read the [Spring Data contribution guidelines](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-data-build/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.adoc).
- [x ] You use the code formatters provided [here](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-data-build/tree/master/etc/ide) and have them applied to your changes. Don’t submit any formatting related changes.
- [ x] You submit test cases (unit or integration tests) that back your changes.
- [ x] You added yourself as author in the headers of the classes you touched. Amend the date range in the Apache license header if needed. For new types, add the license header (copy from another file and set the current year only).

comment.body:
Hello,

I have given more thoughts to your questions and I wanted to clarify some things.

I can't talk for every user of the Specification API, but to me the CriteriaBuilder API is the JPA equivalent of JOOQ/QuerySQL or similar APIs. It allowed a type-safe API that allows you to represent almost any JPA query.

Obviously if a user can represent their query using JPQL and/or a spring data method they would do so.
Specifications / CriteriaBuilder is a lower level API, and is for certain use cases that usually require dynamic queries.

And this comes back to your question related to IDE support and figuring out from the API how many arguments you require.
This is the case for a JPQL query that has static parameters and even a spring data method.
But it is still a runtime error, a user can declare a JPQL query or a spring data method and forget to add a parameter and figure it out later at runtime.

Related to the call point of such an API, to me it's related to the dynamic nature of a Specification, if you have dynamic specifications, then your parameters and/or other values are dynamic as well.

But for simple specifications, the ParametersValues can be extended with multiple of methods.
Technically ParametersValue can be replaced by a Map<String, Value>, I thought initially that I'd require more of an abstraction compared to Map but ultimately it didn't require it.
One advantage other than API/documentation related to not using Map might be also by making ParametersValues immutable.
But if you think Map<String, Object> might be clearer, especially thanks to Map.of and a richer API, then I can handle a refactor.

But  lets assume repository.findAll(spec, ParametersValues.of("param1", val1, "param2", val2")
It won't solve the auto-completion and IDE help, but it will approach the clarity of which parameters are passed near the call site.

But again, to me Specification are used for more dynamic queries already, and this extension would allow even a more dynamic aspect of CriteriaBuilder.
It remains backwards compatible, and perhaps for most users they won't need parameters as well.

But to me the use cases are legitimate for two reasons:

1) Parameters can already be declared with current Specification (Because of CriteriaBuilder) but you can't set the parameters via JPASpecificationExecutor (Repository) so you can't execute them.,
2) This is debatable, but it might be beneficial or desirable to create some decoupling between the "query"/Specification itself, and the data you execute. (See my example of construct a specification in a way where you don't yet have access to the parameters, or when you which to construct it once, and execute it multiple times with multiple values, vs reconstructing the Specification as the values are part of the specification)
3. This is perhaps an edge case, but it is not always possible to have automatic parameters in queries.
In hibernate by default (hibernate.criteria.value_handling_mode is BIND) it will create parameters and bind them if you pass values via CriteriaBuilder e.q equal(expression, Object) but this isn't the case when you are passing a literal.
And in the particular case when using a function call you can only pass literals.

To me all this would do is align the API to be able to execute Specifications that you can't otherwise.

You can currently create specifications that contain parameters, and you will get an exception when running them since you can't set the parameters via the current API.

I hope this convinces you of the legitimacy of this request and I remain available for any further questions.

Thank you.

issue.title: Feature "Rewrite queries using LIKE with wildcards using CONCAT" kills performance on Postgres

labels.name: status: waiting-for-triage
labels.description: An issue we've not yet triaged

labels.name: for: team-attention
labels.description: An issue we need to discuss as a team to make progress

issue.body:
This change introduced in Spring JPA 2.7.13 changes LIKE queries to CONCAT($1, '%') format. However Postgres cannot use table indexes when right-hand side clause has a function (like CONCAT), so invoking query containing CONCAT will perform very poorly on large tables.

As suggested fix this optimization should be optional (e.g. via Spring JPA property setting), and can default to be active. But it should be possible to return to 2.7.12 version of LIKE query.

comment.body:
To add to my original comment, looking at index behavior with LIKE 'ABC%' vs LIKE ( CONCAT ( 'ABC', '%' ) )

The LIKE % results into Index Scan, whereas CONCAT results into SEQ_SCAN which has much worse performance over large tables (> 100M rows).

issue.title: Visibility of `SimpleJpaRepository.ExampleSpecification`

labels.name: status: waiting-for-feedback
labels.description: We need additional information before we can continue

labels.name: status: waiting-for-triage
labels.description: An issue we've not yet triaged

issue.body:
Would it be possible to increase the visibility of `SimpleJpaRepository.ExampleSpecification` from `private` to `protected`?
I'm developing a custom repository that extends `SimpleJpaRepository`, and would like to reuse this inner class as opposed to copying it from the parent. The class in question:

https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-data-jpa/blob/018c2acd86d0a901353036dcdf44eda0bc625bca/spring-data-jpa/src/main/java/org/springframework/data/jpa/repository/support/SimpleJpaRepository.java#L953-L987

https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-data-jpa/blob/018c2acd86d0a901353036dcdf44eda0bc625bca/spring-data-jpa/src/main/java/org/springframework/data/jpa/repository/support/SimpleJpaRepository.java#L953-L987

comment.body:
Fundamentally speaking, `ExampleSpecification` is an implementation detail to provide support for Query by Example.

I'd really to understand the use case you are attempting to solve that begs you to make changes and alterations to `ExampleSpecification`.

comment.body: Spring Data JPA isn't handling any database access at all, your JPA provider handles these aspects. Depending on your JPA provider there are various strategies available. We have examples for Hibernate at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-data-examples/tree/main/jpa/multitenant.

issue.title: Detect Hibernate 5 for HQL Parser support
issue.body:
Hibernate 5.6 supports JPA 3.0, and should be usable with Spring Data JPA 3.1.x. Currently, only Hibernate 6 is detected and allows for the HQL Parser usage. This PR consists in enabling the HQL Parser in the case of Hibernate 5 too.

labels.name: status: pending-design-work

labels.name: for: team-attention

issue.body:
It is possible via the CriteriaBuilder to set up parameters, but parameter values can't be set up if a Specification is ran via a spring repository (via JPASpecificationExecutor)

While it is certainly possible to create custom criterias/queries manually using the EntityManager, it is preferable to be able to set parameter values via Specification/Repository since it's a higher level API.

Using parameters instead of values/literals has multiple advantages:

- Better code design: separating the creation of a specification from the filter values that are applied during execution, especially when having dynamic Specifications with many user defined filter values.
- Shorter queries that don't necessarily leak certain information in the query: While Hibernate might automatically create parameters  and their values for certain Specifications (Notably cb.equal(Expression, Object)  if so configured, it can't do it for all cases, notably for cb.function where the arguments are Expression and you are forced to pass literals

And the code that sets up the parameter values is mostly contained in the query creation code.

The only test method that hasn't duplicated all tests is the findBy variant using a specification and a queryFunction

issue.title: Add the ability to set parameter values for Specifications ran via JpaSpecificationExecutor

labels.name: status: pending-design-work
labels.description: Needs design work before any code can be developed

labels.name: for: team-attention
labels.description: An issue we need to discuss as a team to make progress

issue.body:
It is possible via the CriteriaBuilder to set up parameters, but parameter values can't be set up if a Specification is ran via a spring repository (via JPASpecificationExecutor)

While it is certainly possible to create custom criterias/queries manually using the EntityManager, it is preferable to be able to set parameter values via Specification/Repository since it's a higher level API.

Using parameters instead of values/literals has multiple advantages:

- Better code design: separating the creation of a specification from the filter values that are applied during execution, especially when having dynamic Specifications with many user defined filter values.
- Shorter queries that don't necessarily leak certain information in the query: While Hibernate might automatically create parameters  and their values for certain Specifications (Notably cb.equal(Expression, Object)  if so configured, it can't do it for all cases, notably for cb.function where the arguments are Expression and you are forced to pass literals


This Pull Request adds a new record class ParametersValues in the same package as the Specification, that servers as a way to hold parameter name -> parameter values.

All methods in JPASpecificationExecutor that took Specifications as an argument now have variants that take ParametersValues as an argument as well

In the implementation in SimpleJpaRepository the methods without a ParamatersValues simply delegate their call to the counterparts with such an argument.

And the code that sets up the parameter values is mostly contained in the query creation code.

Test methods have been extended based on existing tests, but instead of using values, Specification using parameters were used instead.

The only test method that hasn't duplicated all tests is the findBy variant using a specification and a queryFunction
This is because the other tests verify mostly behaviour related to the queryFunction, and since the code is shared, only a single test was created to test that paramterValues are actually set

Thank you.

- [x ] You have read the [Spring Data contribution guidelines](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-data-build/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.adoc).
- [x ] You use the code formatters provided [here](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-data-build/tree/master/etc/ide) and have them applied to your changes. Don’t submit any formatting related changes.

comment.body:
> The beauty of `Specification` is that it can be used as lambda. Introducing another variant makes usage much more complex.

It will not break existing behavior, but add the ability to set parameter. `JpaSpecificationExecutor` will not be changed.
